addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the Erle of Essex./

page.lettertext:
fol.109r
May it please yo
r
good L. It was yo
r
pleasure to
will me, when I parted from home, to write of any
thing whatseover, so I write unto yo
w
often: w
ch
order I will folowe, till yo
r
L. be weery, and
bidde me to take an other course.
M
r
De
n
iston
the Scottishe Ambassado
r
ligger hath bin w[t me of pur-
pose to ease his stomacke of dislike of this comming hi-
ther of
Coronel Stuart
: aswell in respect of his
demaunde of assistance, w
ch
if it be mony, he thinkes
is wholy lost: as of
e mariage solicited between
the
Erle of Orchney
and
e
sister
of
Co. Maurice
:
under coulo
r
wherof he saieth
at Coronel Stuart doth
practise somwhat els: and yet for ought I can per-
ceave, he seemeth to be ignorant of his privat In-
structions. And thus he uttereth his phansie not
onely to me, but in secret communication to divers
of
e states: albeit as I am informed, he is a creature
of
e
Chancello
r
aswell as
e Coronel. Both by
him and
e rest of
e nation heere Stuart is re-
puted a papist, and a Spaniard in hart, and of
a busie disposition: not, as they affirme, beloved
of
e
King
nor of many men in
Scotland.
And
though they speake it I finde somw
at
of the splene,
yet [.] [.] in one common conceat,
I will take it [.] [.] [.] his procee-
dinges. The 26 of
e last I sent
yo
r
L.
e copies of certaine l
re
s intercepted, in
w
ch
was a note of speciall personage, that would
be [wonne] as he thought, to doe a singular peece of
service if meanes might be founde to rec
o
pense his
losses
fol.109v
I have bin somwhat inquisitive, to knowe among
e
Scottes, who
at partie might be by their conjecture.
But they are all in a muse, not knowing whome to
ghesse at: though their chiefest suspic
o
n [sturre] upon
the L. Humes, by reason of alliance between him and
Thomas Tyrie
. The Coronel in his discourse doth rather
ghesse
e
L. Athol
, partly for
e affection
at he bea-
reth to
Bothwell
, and partly for a [.] w
ch
he
saieth is growen of late between him and
Argile.
I can not yet perce ave by any [.] heere,
at
Stuart hath imparted his privat Instructions to any
one of
e state: w
ch
makes me thinke if his charge
was to proceede in suche sort as he should finde mens
dispositions: wherein I thinke he is deceaved.
I have had a l
re
from yo
r
L. by
Cap
t
Berry
wher-
of
e date was omitted, and
e [tenor was onely to]
lette me now that her
Ma
tie
[complained] of my si-
lence in w
ch
behalf I trust by this she is very well
satisfied.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage Marche 2 1594.
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
